data.text: 7 ways to be insanely productive that no one is talking about:

urls.title: Untethered Mind by Alex Mathers
urls.description: The newsletter to help free you from your mental limits, grow more confident, make more money, and enjoy freedom. Receive regular, enlivening ideas on mindset, psychology, money mindset, spirituality, productivity, business mindset, energy management. Click to read Untethered Mind by Alex Mathers, a Substack publication with tens of thousands of readers.

7 ways to be insanely productive that no one is talking about:

5. Outsource work you donâ€™t need to do
6. Spend more time in the same place
7. Enjoy the pain.

RECAP

7 ways to be insanely productive that no one is talking about:

1. Stop trying to be disciplined
2. Honour your natural rhythm
3. Donâ€™t set goals without assigning a system
4. Regularly shake stress out of your hips

Because on the other side of discomfort and even pain is opportunity in the form of insane physical reserves and outer-worldly creative potential. 

If you can find a strange love for pain, you will do more. 

You will become a maniac that others can only watch in awe.

ðŸ”†

7. Enjoy the pain.

Many of us are overly obsessed with feelings. 

We need to be in the ideal mood to do things. 

â€˜Itâ€™s important for our creativity,â€™ we say. 

But this mindset is blocking your potential. How come?

I donâ€™t leave the scene. 

I stay there with butt firmly planted on seat.

I take some breaks to stretch, but if I stay in the same place, Iâ€™m more likely to produce more.

6. Spend more time in the same place.

If we keep changing our environment, we diminish our attention to any one thing. 

When I write, and especially if Iâ€™m in a good productive flow, I keep going if I can.

If youâ€™re spending time on tedious tasks, what else could you do that is higher leverage, given your talents? 

Use Upwork or Fiverr and pay others to create more time. 

Productivity isnâ€™t about how busy you are. 

Itâ€™s about the results you produce under your management.

5. Outsource work you donâ€™t need to do.

Most will never subcontract jobs because they are too precious about how they want the work done, or they canâ€™t understand valuing their time as money spent.

Instead of crying to mummy, they throw on some dubstep and gyrate like a crazed ape on amphetamines. 

They unlock their hips and canâ€™t help breaking into a massive grin at the sense of relief and boundless creativity that rewards them.

4. Regularly shake stress out of your hips.

Much of our accumulated stresses and concerns are not actually floating around in our heads. 

Thinking this makes us insecure and run off in search of a therapist. 

The true productive Gs have a dirty little secret.

This would look like writing 2000 words per day from 10am to 12pm without distraction using the Pomodoro technique with an accountability partner. 

Anything is possible with the correct system attached.

If I genuinely want to commit to a goal becoming a reality, I always assign a system to that goal. 

If your goal doesnâ€™t have a system, you will not achieve that goal. 

If I want to write and complete a book, I design a system for its creation.

3. Donâ€™t set goals without assigning a system.

Writing out my goals is an invigorating process. 

More than anything, it keeps my attention on the exciting things that are possible in my life.
But if you tend to work better in the evenings, forget Nathan, the life coach, this time and do what comes with less forcing.

2. Honour your natural rhythm.

Forget the gurus, and listen to what works for your body. 

This becomes clearer to you when you live healthier, though, so donâ€™t come to rely too heavily on your overly stimulated body as an indicator of whatâ€™s best.

Write one message to a potential client. 

Do what you need to do, but take a tiny action.

This will lead to an accumulation of actions, and people will wonder how youâ€™ve become so â€˜disciplined.â€™

Instead of trying to improve, just focus on the next, easy step. 

Thatâ€™s all you need to do. Make it super easy. 

Write a line. 

Put on your running shoes.

1. Stop trying to be disciplined.

We can often berate ourselves for being lazy. 

Weâ€™re frustrated when we continually procrastinate. 

But itâ€™s not that we lack discipline. 

We apply so much pressure to perform that we overwhelm ourselves.
